keystone/common/sql/migrations/env.py.message: how come render as batch?  this changes things a lot

OK so render as batch applies to the "alembic autogenerate" function, which is a code generation function.  When this runs, it's comparing the current ORM model in this case to what's present in a live database and generating Python code that it puts into a .py file.   

The thing that the directive does is it causes operations that alter tables to be rendered inside of a "batch_op" code block.   So the immediate effect is that it changes the structure of the generated Python code.   The code is rendered that way regardless of what database backend is in use because render_as_batch=True means to do it.

So, what happens then ?  The "batch_op" code block itself is essentially a no-op for PostgreSQL and MySQL, assuming its arguments are left at their defaults.

So basically, render_as_batch should not have any effect on MySQL and PostgreSQL, but it instead determines how the generated .py files look.

If we are indeed migrating from sqlalchemy-migrate to SQlite, then yes it seems likely this needs to be present.  where I dont know as much what's happening here is that keystone already has alembic code going on within it, so I dont really understand the pre-existing combination of sqlalchemy-migrate and alembic that was here previously.

I needed this in nova to allow the auto-generated migrations to work with SQLite, which is used for most of the tests. afaict, it should have no effect for MySQL or PostgreSQL (i.e. production) backends, right?
That makes sense, thanks for the detailed analysis!

As this is marked as unresolved, Mike and/or Stephen, can you confirm that this parameter is ignored in MySQL and PostrgreSQL connections? The documentation points out this was implemented for SQLite, but it doesn't say you can't use it with other drivers... I would have to test it out to know the real behavior.

tests/unit/test_sos.py.message:
Is it sufficient to know both changes were merged by sched1 to know the cache was properly cleared and rebuilt? Or is it possible that the stale cache would be valid?

In particular we didn't update either change during the period of time that sched1 missed so I wonder if the entries there would still be valid and we could merge code here successfully even without clearing?

Ah, sorry for the missing context.  Without this fix, what happens is that we enqueue the old Change object from the first pass because we pull it from the cache (since we're enqueing a dependency, it comes from the pipeline cache).  Then we start reporting and therefore updating the change objects from within the pipeline processing.  Since we're updating them, we try to put them in the ZK change cache, and that fails because the Change object we're passing in is not the Python Change object that is in the ZK change cache.  It throws an exception and the pipeline processing bails.

This is the exception it hits: https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/zk/change_cache.py#L409-L413

So tl;dr -- it is sufficient because sched1 tries to write an update to the change as it's reporting and that update causes the cache collision.

Yes, except it's not ZK records because this is all in-memory.  So it's more like to handle subtracting a QuotaInfo with one specification from another QuotaInfo that doesn't have it.  For example, a Provider that doesn't specify a quota for high-memory instances (but to math.inf) and an instance that specifies it needs one high memory instance.  We need that to end up being "math.inf-1=math.inf".  This initializes the first operand in that case.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
First of all thanks for pointing out the problem.

However, I don't think this is the right direction. What we require here is to use the hypervisor name which is consistent with libvirt, the most popular virt driver we believe. If we use a different logic in neutron then that can break consistency in some deployments according to how dns servers or /etc/hosts are configured.

IMHO we should keep the current logic which comes from libvirt to keep the consistency as much as possible and find the solution within eventlet.

test/probe/test_sharder.py.message:
doesn't starting this again before the replicators run means the unsharded one without objects, gets the objects from the others?

If were just sharding 2 and then deleting objects we could probably just do that.. probably don't need to turn the unsharded off.

If you want to mark the unsharded as deleted because it has no objects while others do, then you want to replicate before starting the handoff half I believe.

good point! The objects get deleted later - I think I was concerned that the delete updates would got to shards and not roots and so the unsharded root needed to not get the original PUTs in order to be empty. But you're right, the replication before sharding would sync the object rows anyway, and the proxies will be caching out of date container info so delete updates do go to the root.

nova/objects/service.py.message: I think this is too big of a hammer. You can make this call to determine the version of services in a cell other than computes. For example, we may need to make this call to determine the versions of all the APIs (which should be pointing to cell0) or scheduler or conductor, etc.

Okay, looking at how this plumbs in, *IF* we're going to make a change here, we probably need to have a flag to this method which is skip_cell0=False, and if true, use the skip_cell0 scatter variant as you've noted here. Then pass that as True from the compute-specific utils.raise_if_old_compute() thing.

That said, I think that the root cause of the problem is the use of the templated hostname in a situation where not all the DBs are on the same host as all the services that may need to access it. Fixing the cell0 special case here doesn't fix the situation where lots of cells are spread across multiple hosts and not all of them can access each other. That makes me think it's best not to make the somewhat obscure cell0 change here, as it's really just an artifact of how this one tripleo setup is wired.

I think we've previously said that anything with api_database set is assumed to be able to contact all the cells. In this case, that's what's going on - we're starting up from a service with api_database set. If you've got that set on cell conductors for the affinity check, then you need to have the other cells accessible to cell conductors. If you're not, then you can have that isolation. We could introduce another flag that tells something whether it has global scope or not, but I think I'd rather not do that and just keep it simple.

Suppose two ports with ip 10.1.1.10 and 10.1.1.11 exist in subnet private-subnet, but they have not been attached to any device. Now, a user runs:

  - openstack.cloud.router:
    cloud: mycloud
    state: present
    name: router2
    network: ext_network1
    interfaces:
      - net: private-net
        subnet: private-subnet
        portip: 10.1.1.10

Later, the user runs:

  - openstack.cloud.router:
    cloud: mycloud
    state: present
    name: router2
    network: ext_network1
    interfaces:
      - net: private-net
        subnet: private-subnet
        portip: 10.1.1.10
      - net: private-net
        subnet: private-subnet
        portip: 10.1.1.11

Will the second port be added to the router since missing_port_ids has been dropped?
Thank you very much!

Not sure how valid this specification is. In my tests, the neutron API returns a "400: Bad router request: Router already has a port on subnet" error when I try to do it this way.

Not sure what to do in this case. Let it throw an error (or warning?)? merge the two addresses into a single port? Right now it'll silently ignore one.

Thanks for testing this! Actually Neutron never allowed a router to be attached twice to the same subnet [1][2].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/9355885d7dab41e48a8ecaaf59b1bd3835f17f27
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/3005d16fe3588bdf4b928e79f640b991df9fae3b

But this portip attribute introduces a lot more cases which we do not currently do not implement. For example, suppose the user runs:

  - openstack.cloud.router:
    cloud: mycloud
    state: present
    name: router2
    network: ext_network1
    interfaces:
      - net: private-net
        subnet: private-subnet

and this will auto-assign portip 10.1.1.10 on private-subnet to router2. Later, the user runs:

  - openstack.cloud.router:
    cloud: mycloud
    state: present
    name: router2
    network: ext_network1
    interfaces:
      - net: private-net
        subnet: private-subnet
        portip: 10.1.1.11

One would expect our module to detach/remove the port with ip 10.1.1.10 and assign 10.1.1.11 to router2. So we should (re)add some logic to add or remove specific ports/portips. Once we have that, we let Neutron handle the case of two ports on the same subnet, i.e. we let Neutron report an error on that.
I've gone ahead and added logic to handle that case, as well as a test case that exercises it.

cinder/volume/drivers/yadro/tatlin_clien.message: Remove use of six. We only support python 3 and do not want compatibility code for python 2 included.

You may want to think about refactoring this at some point.  Most people know that a variable beginning with '_' should be treated as private (although that's not enforced by the runtime), but there's a mix here of string constants and vars that will actually be modified (like _api).  Usually something that you want to be treated like a constant is named with ALL_CAPS.  Most drivers handle this by declaring the constants in a utility file or something.  The only reason to observe the convention is that when someone has to maintain the driver later on, it's less likely they'll be confused.
These can be directly declared and initialized in the __init__ method, don't see a need for defining them here.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: As with the rabbit charm, I'm struggling a bit with this change. This seems to update the charm to add relation data to the nrpe charm about the required cpu governor setting. But I don't see why this charm should have an opinion about this. Perhaps the nrpe subordinate should have a cpu governor charm option or this should be managed by some other subordinate.

This change is part of a series that cover several principle charms. I just realized, this one and the one in rabbit are actually duplicates of previous unfinished work that I was not aware of...

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-nova-compute/+/807293

In the Same topic there is also an open one in rabbit and a merged one in percona cluster.

As to the need for this change, the subordinate NRPE charm already has a config option for this but it is unset by default. The specification in BSENG-74 says this check needs to be configurable through this key by the principle charm via the relation in case it is unset in the subordinate config. So this value 'performance' is given as an initial value to the check.

I am planning to abandon my duplicates to avoid confusion. I think we should move this discussion under the original pull requests.

If rbd_flatten_volume_from_snapshot is enabled (it's off by default), then when creation of volume C completes at step 3, there should no longer be a relation between snapshot B and volume C, so even with volume C in the trash, the user should be able to delete snapshot B at step 5.  (I think.)

zuul/model.py.message: nit: I think this should be BuildReference

I think we should have some sanity checks here to ensure that all build references were replaced.

I can imagine there are cases where the referenced build is no longer in ZK e.g. because of a partially reported bundle (ZK connection interrupted or other exceptions that would abort the pipeline processing). This could lead to a broken pipeline state that would require manual intervention to fix.

Probably the best thing to do in that case would be to remove the build.  Presumably the scheduler will correct the situation (either by continuing to dequeue the item or continue to create a new buildset).
Should we add _path to the init list of attributes on the Build class? This is the sort of thing that python3.11 takes advantage of to be quicker.
Oops, we don't need it here, we can remove.

Yeah, the user has to queue an image and then wait/poll to see if it ever shows up in the cached list. I guess the other problem here is that even though we've set the devstack g-api-r interval to ten seconds, tempest needs to run on production clouds for validation reasons. Someone could easily have their interval set at 60 minutes or more and the test will not have any recourse other than to assume the feature is broken and report failure.

I guess I'd like to revisit the idea of a manual trigger as I think that's really how a lot of people will want this to work anyway.

cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powerstor.message:
What's the reasoning behind this?

nfs_qcow2_volumes being true is not the only way to end up with a qcow2-formatted volume file -- you can start with a raw volume and end up with a qcow2-formatted volume by creating and deleting snapshots while attached.
Also, online snapshots will not work if attached to multiple instances.
the original idea was to add support of multiattach. Multiattach cannot work over NFS with qcow2 volumes.
we talk about online snapshots, right? Would it be possible to snapshot shut instance disks while the latter are multi-attached to different hosts?
Raw volumes can be multiattached while qcow2 can't. I'm aware that online snapshots will be created as qcow2 files. However, snapshots are disabled by default.

Thanks for review.
Now driver throws an exception when creating snapshot for volume with enabled multiattach.
I've also mentioned this in documentation.

> we talk about online snapshots, right? Would it be possible to snapshot shut instance disks while the latter are multi-attached to different hosts?

probably does not make sense since raw disks become qcow2, as Eric mentioned earlier

Snapshots are disabled by default, but what happens if an operator sets nfs_snapshot_support=True ?  If you don't want snapshots under any circumstances (and it sounds like you don't, so that you can have multiattach), you should probably override create_snapshot() so that it raises an exception, instead of relying on _check_snapshot_support() in the nfs driver to raise depending on the value of the config option.

I'm trying to figure out if there's anything else we need to worry about.  We have this dynamic check when someone requests a snapshot that will not allow the request if the volume is of a multiattach-capable type.  So we won't go from raw->qcow2.

In the other direction, when we want to multiattach a volume, we are relying on if an operator has nfs_qcow2_volumes=True, this driver will not report as multiattach capable, and so a request to build a multiattach capable volume will not land on this backend.  So we'll never be in the situation where an operator starts cinder with nfs_qcow2_volumes=True, operates for a while, then switches nfs_qcow2_volumes=False, and then someone tries to multiattach a qcow2.  Is that correct?
Right now we can create snapshot when multiattach is enabled.

We rely on the fact that administrator or other person responsible for managing services know what they do.
For example, the backend may become broken if administrator changes storage password or storage IP address in the configuration file. After that all volumes become unavailable.
Also, I haven't found another way of how to restrict multiattach.

-1: We have a problem here:

- Configure driver to do raw volumes
- Create volume with non multi-attach type
- Create a snapshot -> current backing file is qcow2
- Retype volume to multi-attach type (same as the old type but just setting it to multi-attach)
- Attach volume to multiple instances

And we end up attaching a QCOW2 file to multiple instances.
we will disable snapshot and qcow2 support in favor of future storage side copy/clone facility

I understand that this wants to reuse generic nfs driver methods but i think it's still better to have some separation in terms of few config parameters that are dynamically determined by remotefs driver and similarly is implemented in other filesystem type drivers.
This will also help in a multibackend deployment when generic nfs and PowerStore NFS are both configured.
(Taking quobyte driver examples)

1) config params for sparsed volumes and qcow2 volumes[1] will is dynamically determined during volume create in remotefs driver[2]
2) it's more preferable to have different directories for different driver mountpoints hence driver mount point base config[3] which will also require you to set self.base parameter during initialization[4] for nfs[5]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/drivers/quobyte.py#L49-L55
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/drivers/remotefs.py#L315-L325
[3] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/drivers/quobyte.py#L56-L59
[4] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/drivers/quobyte.py#L263
[5] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/volume/drivers/nfs.py#L104-L105

I don't see problem having different nfs mount bases - each driver section can have different values for well known parameters, e.g.

[generic-nfs]
volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.nfs.NfsDriver
volume_backend_name = generic-nfs
nas_host = 10.20.30.1
nas_share_path = /psopen
nfs_mount_point_base = $state_path/generic_mounts
nfs_sparsed_volumes = False

[powerstore-nfs]
volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.dell_emc.powerstore.driver.PowerStoreNFSDriver
volume_backend_name = powerstore-nfs
nas_host = 10.20.30.2

I think what's happening here is that the easy case is when a controller has one namespace, then you just disconnect it; but if controller has two namespaces, you can't disconnect it because you may break a connection to something in use, and if it's got no namespaces, you can just go ahead and disconnect it.

0 => Disconnect
2 or more => Leave

.zuul.yaml.message:
I think you can do
    files: &rbd_files
    
here to create the "rbd_files" variable, and then in irrelevant_files below for the nv job, use

    irrelevant_files: *rbd_files
      - other/file/a
      - other/file/b

I thought about that, but it's illegal YAML (at least according to http://www.yamllint.com/ ).  And if you try

    irrelevant_files: 
      - *rbd_files
      - other/file/a
      - other/file/b
 
YAML sees that as a 3 item list, the first element of which is itself a list.  I don't know if zuul has implemented list flattening.  YAML errors get picked up immediately by zuul, so it will be quick to find out if this works.
?: Should we have it as well for the gate jobs?  Or we can do it later.

While this test is correctly asserting the expected behavior this test can pass for two different reasons:
a) the code is correct and nova enforces zone2
b) nova does not enforce any zone (bug) but the scheduler selected host2 (zone2) by chance

While OSC is bound to the OpenStack release cycle our target is to have OSC running with older clouds. This eventually mean we may be even running older python versions. For switching to 3.9 for building container image there are no issues. But I have issues with dropping support declaration for 3.6, 3.7 without real need (our code as of now should be working fine with it). Let us not do this

> While OSC is bound to the OpenStack release cycle our target is to have OSC running with older clouds.

Clouds != local environment. I agree with supporting older clouds. I don't think we need to support older environments (e.g. Ubuntu 16.04) though.

> This eventually mean we may be even running older python versions.

On the clouds hosts, maybe, but this isn't really being used there (or doesn't have to be used there).

> For switching to 3.9 for building container image there are no issues. But I have issues with dropping support declaration for 3.6, 3.7 without real need (our code as of now should be working fine with it). Let us not do this

This is invariably going to happen anyway. Many of our dependencies have already dropped support for Python 3.6 and 3.7. Thankfully they have all set 'python_requires' correctly, as expected, so pip is simply installing the older version there. However, we won't pick up any new features or bugfixes (including security fixes) for these.

Surely not Ubuntu 16.04, but we (at least on our cloud) still have some users sitting on CentOS 7 VMs (don't ask me why, please). And as such this mostly means 3.6 or 3.7. I do not really want us to chase ancient versions of python, neither doing extra work on keeping compatibility, but dropping something what works now is a different story.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
The workflow is not correct. The patch should be backported to stable/yoga first, then the commit from stable/yoga should be backported to stable/xena, the stable/xena commit to stable/wallaby, etc...
with this method, if you fix a merge conflict when backporting from n to n-1, you prevent a merge conflict when backporting to n-2

I would also recommend using "git cherry-pick -x <ref>" when creating a backport. -x adds a line in the commit message of the backport that indicates the id of the commit the backport was created from. so if you're commit on master is 1234567,
the commit on yoga will show

"(cherry picked from commit 1234567)"

then the commit on xena will show

"(cherry picked from commit 1234567)
(cherry picked from commit <yoga commit>)"

another advice, in case of merge conflict, when calling "git commit", git automatically adds details about the conflict in the commit message, but those details are commented, please uncomment those lines, it helps reviewers to focus on potential issues in the backport

(a merge conflict is displayed as
"Conflict:
   path/to/my/file1
   path/to/my/file2")
Thanks for the detailed guide Greg! I will give it a try soon.

Thanks for backporting your fix.

For all stable branches you cherry-picked from the same commit on master. This works of course, but it is not the correct workflow. Correct would be to cherry-pick from the last backport, in this case from your stable/yoga backport. That would add another line

(cherry picked from commit 74f2baf539359f5ded2bc01b28d570083bc0a797)

to this commit message and, more importantly, would automatically include modifications you made in previous backports (e.g. merge conflict resolutions).

According to the commit message in your backports there were no merge conflicts, so you could simply fix this by adding those "(cherry picked from commit ...)" to your commit messages as described above. An example how it should look like: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/octavia/+/847563

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
-1 for this since
thise really should be Related-Bug:

if you use the neutron api closes woudl be fine but tempest should ideally avoid using the proxy apis in nova in thest that are not explcitly testing the proxy apis.

so nova proxy apis for neutron shoudl be avoided in the senario tests.

I've changed it to Related-bug, but at least in Nova's api-ref for the 'show server details' API that tempest is hitting to assert that the floating IP has been associated correctly [1], I can find no mention of the deprecation of server['addresses'].

I'm not against changing Tempest to stop using that field if it's really deprecated, but:

1. That smells like a big chunk of work
2. Nova would have to properly mark is as deprecated, like we did for the image, interfaces, volumes etc proxy APIs.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=show-server-details-detail#show-server-details

Based on my testing on tripleo-ci jobs:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/850156/1#message-977af8b73a09f8b161a4fb408cab2aec369b8369

here are the results:
https://d3e2fe24de71030ee8aa-add3baf7d164319a1fbb45a2e58a56e9.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/850156/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-9-standalone/1d100da/logs/undercloud/var/log/tempest/tempest_run.log

```
{0} tempest.scenario.test_minimum_basic.TestMinimumBasicScenario.test_minimum_basic_instance_hard_reboot_after_vol_snap_deletion [104.413968s] ... ok
```

and

https://4dd0377b7a30aa622b30-38e6ee403788ae1bf863236e5a7d9ac3.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/850156/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-9-standalone-fips/3409145/logs/undercloud/var/log/tempest/tempest_run.log

```
{0} tempest.scenario.test_minimum_basic.TestMinimumBasicScenario.test_minimum_basic_instance_hard_reboot_after_vol_snap_deletion [132.275445s] ... ok
```
We can merge this change.
I think it is good, and later we can add a method to use Neutron API for FIP check

sure this can be improved later but i jsut want to be clear that
if a floating ip is reported form nova api as associated with the vm its
has no baring on if that floating ip can be used to connect to the vm.

nova just provides a cached view on the data stored in the neutron db.
neutron is the only source of truth for floating ip to fixed ip mapping.
Let's merge to fix the issue, it's basically the same what we've done for this other test in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/811191

tempest/scenario/manager.py.message: a better fix would be to actully call neutron to get this info isntead of useing the deprecated proxy apis in nova.

If I understand it correctly it might happen that the wait_for_server_floating_ip() function can end successfully even though the floating IP is not fully associated with a port? 

I am not sure how important this is but if this is true, it sounds to me like the wait_for_server_floating_ip() needs to be fixed.

Would be good but I don't think that Neutron API can give back this information, I mean that a FIP is used by a VM, or it would be something like this:
* Check the server uuid
* Get the FIP which has the port_details['device_id'] as the server uuid
* Check the FIP floating_ip_address
* Check the FIP port_details['status'] = ACTIVE

After thinking on it perhaps not much more steps than what we have now in wait_for_server_floating_ip
seems like it could be a good improvement of the waiter - to check the above mentioned association of an FIP with the port.

nova is getting its floating IP info from neutron.
the associations are stored in the neutron DB and we
cache that info in nova network_info_cache as part of the fixed IP object
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/model.py#L261-L262=

but that cache and take multiple minutes to update passive or will be actively rebuild only after we receive a network-vif changed event from neutron.

so neutron is the source of truth for fip info.

all you have to check is that the floating IP is associated with a neutron port

when a floating IP is reported vai nova api that does not provide any gurarentee that that floating ip is assocated with the port at the dataplane level.

neutron notifies nova of the accoration fo the floating ip with the port/fixed ip when the ascoiated is done in the db not after its set up in the set up in the dataplane. so there is not added value in retriving this info form nova instead of driectly form neutron.

if we add this here, then test_minimum_basic_scenario test will call this waiter twice - once as part of this method and once right after it - see https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/commit/97be23ea6402649652991983f3f2b85873eba4d8/tempest/scenario/test_minimum_basic.py#L144-L147

We should either remove the first wait_for_server_floating_ip call (right after calling associate_floating_ip) from the test_minimum_basic_scenario test or put this waiter directly to the test_minimum_basic_instance_hard_reboot_after_vol_snap_deletion test instead.

I'm for option 2 (putting the waiter to the test_minimum_basic_instance_hard_reboot_after_vol_snap_deletion test) as associate_floating_ip is called from multiple different tests (maybe even plugins) and waiting for the floating ip is not always required, why prolong the execution by waiting for the ip then?
